title: Innovative Toothpaste from Keratin Repairs Enamel
summary: Researchers have identified keratin, a protein commonly found in human hair and skin, as a key component for repairing and protecting tooth enamel. This material creates a mineralized layer that effectively halts tooth decay and restores strength to teeth, showing superior performance compared to traditional fluoride-based treatments. Sourced from sustainable materials like hair, this innovation could soon be integrated into commercial toothpaste or gels. The discovery has the potential to revolutionize dentistry by transforming waste products into effective tools for tooth regeneration. This approach not only addresses dental health issues but also promotes environmental sustainability by utilizing renewable resources. If developed further, it could reduce the prevalence of cavities and enhance oral care practices globally.

background_read: Tooth enamel is the hardest substance in the human body, but it can erode due to acids from bacteria and diet, leading to cavities. Traditional prevention methods include fluoride, which helps remineralize enamel, but it has limitations. Keratin, a protein found in hair, nails, and skin, is known for its strength and is now being explored for dental applications. This research highlights how bio-based materials can offer sustainable solutions by repurposing waste. Understanding these advances requires knowledge of basic biology and environmental science, as they merge health innovation with eco-friendly practices. This could lead to more effective oral care products and reduce the environmental footprint of dental treatments.
